original_data.question: A 64-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of bilateral knee pain that has been present for the past several years but has worsened recently. He reports pain with climbing stairs and with extended walks of greater than 100 yards. The pain worsens with activity throughout the day and is alleviated by periods of rest. He states that he has minimal morning stiffness, lasting approximately 5-10 minutes after waking up most days. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the bony structures on the medial aspect of the bilateral knees as well as crepitus and a decreased range of motion, limited at the extremes of flexion and extension. Both knee joints are cool to touch and exhibit bony enlargement upon palpation of the medial joint line. Which of the following studies would be indicated for further work-up of this patient's presenting condition?

model_response:
The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis of the knee. The history of worsening pain with activity and relief with rest, tenderness along the medial joint lines, crepitus, and decreased range of motion are all characteristic of this condition. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative bone disease that most commonly affects the knees, hips, and thumb base in older individuals. It is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals over the age of 55. Risk factors include obesity, previous injury, and occupations that require heavy use of the knees. The diagnosis is clinical, and radiographs may be obtained for confirmation. However, in the absence of symptomatic neurologic or systemic inflammatory disease, there is no need for further workup. A CBC and ESR would be useful in the evaluation of inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis or infection. An MRI of the knee would be useful in the evaluation of ligamentous or meniscal injury, but the clinical presentation and physical examination findings in this patient are more consistent with osteoarthritis.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Providers of initial care for patients. These PHYSICIANS refer patients when appropriate for secondary or specialist care.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the knee. [UToronto:chum]
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
In an declined condition.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
Ascending or descending stairs.
To increase in length or duration.
A traditional unit of length equal to 3 feet, or 36 inches, or 0.9144 meter.
Body movements of a human or an animal as a behavioral phenomenon.
Occurring or done each day.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Freedom from activity.
A constituent administrative district of a nation.
Description:Provides more than identified, but not as much as universal. There are not expected to be many of these.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A dull achy pain.
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.
The structural organ comprised of specialized connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.
Toward the middle or inside (as opposed to lateral).
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
A region of the lower extremity immediately surrounding and including the KNEE JOINT.
Air trapped in the subcutaneous space. It can be palpated or heard as a crackling or grating sensation under the skin.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.
The highest degree of severity.
Tests for iliosacral or sacroiliac somatic dysfunction.
To increase in length or duration.
A synovial hinge connection formed between the bones of the FEMUR; TIBIA; and PATELLA.
To lower the temperature of something.
Placing of the hands of the healer upon the person to be cured with the intent of spiritual energetic healing.
General increase in bulk of a part or organ due to CELL ENLARGEMENT and accumulation of FLUIDS AND SECRETIONS, not due to tumor formation, nor to an increase in the number of cells (HYPERPLASIA).
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
